name: 2-pyridineacetamide
Reason: 2-pyridineacetamide has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of pyridine, which has a melting point of -15.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The pyridine ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and pi-pi interactions, estimated at around +20°C. The acetamide group can participate in hydrogen bonding, which may raise the melting point by approximately +10°C. The carbonyl group introduces a rigid structure and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10°C. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to its small size and limited ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around -5°C.
